I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on  proposed loans 

1. 
to the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for the Southern Road Connectivity Project.1 
 
2. 
The  project  will  improve  connectivity  between  the  expressway  and  local  transport 
networks  in  the  southern  region.2 Capacity  will  be  improved  on  33  kilometers  (km)  of  national 
highways  linking  three  expressway  interchanges,  and  the  capacity  of  the  Road  Development 
Authority  (RDA)  will  be  enhanced  in  planning  the  expressway  connectivity  improvement  and 
ensuring  project  implementation  readiness.  By  amplifying  the  benefits  of  the  country’s  first 
expressway  network,  the  project  will  contribute  to  one  of  the  Government  of  Sri  Lanka’s  key 
development goals, which is to develop the country into a regional trading center between the 
East  and West.  It  will  also  improve  access  to  economic  opportunities,  as  well  as  basic  social, 
health, and education facilities. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
After  the  end  of  its  three  decades  of  civil  conflict  in  May  2009,  Sri  Lanka  achieved  
economic  growth  exceeding  8%  annually  in  2010  and  2011.  The  economy  slowed  to  6.4%  in 
2012 due to weak external demand, drought, and floods, but it is expected to edge up in 2013 
and  2014.3 Sri  Lanka’s  strategic  location  at  the  crossroads  of  regional  maritime  trading  routes 
has  contributed  to  its  growth.  The  transport  sector  contributed  12%  of  the  country’s  gross 
domestic  product  in  2011,  which  compares  to  7.9%  in  2005.  To  fully  utilize  the  country’s 
strategic location in the trading routes, the government has focused on developing five strategic 
global hubs (aviation, naval, knowledge, commerce, and energy).4 Public investments are being 
made  to  developing  several  mega-infrastructures,  including  Colombo  seaport,  Katunayake 
airport,  Hambantota  seaport,  Hambantota  airport,  and  an  expressway  network  connecting  the 
international trading facilities.  
 
4. 
The  government  envisages  Western  Province,  with  its  rich  natural  and  human 
resources,  as  a  regional  center  hub  and  Southern  Province  as  a  strategic  area  on  the 
international trading corridor complementary to Western Province. Western Province drives the 
country’s economy, contributing more than 45% of national gross domestic product in 2010. It is 
also the  most  densely  populated  province  in Sri Lanka  and  has the  highest  vehicle ownership 
rate.  Southern  Province,  with  the  second-highest  vehicle  ownership  rate  in  the  country,  is 
closely integrated with Western Province through physical and economic connections. With the 
function  of  international  hub  being  developed  in  Colombo  and  Hambantota  of  Western  and 
Southern  provinces,  respectively,  the  country’s  future  sustainable  growth  demands  an 
integrated  inland  transport  system  (and  particularly  in  the  southern  region)  to  efficiently  move 
people and goods.

The  current  inland  transport  system  is  dominated  by  the  road  network.  Road  transport 
5. 
accounts  for  95%  of  passenger-kilometers  and  98%  of  freight  ton-kilometers.  With  its 
comprehensive  road  network  comprising  about  96  km  of  expressway,  11,922  km  of  national 
roads,  15,975  km  of  provincial  roads,  and  80,000  km  of  local  roads,  the  country’s  population 
and centers  of  economic  activity  are  well  covered. The  average  vehicle ownership rate for  Sri 
Lanka  is  estimated  at  about  152  vehicles  per  1,000  persons  in  2011  after  average  annual 
growth  of  11.4%  since  2007.  It  is  estimated  that  to  maintain  the  current  levels  of  transport 
services, road capacity would need to be doubled every 8–10 years.  
 
6. 
The  transport  sector’s  most  significant  accomplishment  in  connecting  the  international 
trading  facilities  was  the  commissioning  of  the  Southern  Expressway  on  27  November  2011. 
The Southern Transport Development Project laid the foundations for modernizing the country’s 
transport sector by completing a 96 km expressway, the first of its kind in Sri Lanka.5  After the 
expressway  was  opened,  the  travel  time  between  Kottawa  of  Western  Province  and  Galle  of 
Southern  Province  was  reduced  from  5  hours  to  1.5  hours.  Aside  from  the  Southern 
Expressway, three additional projects in the southern region are ongoing to further develop the 
expressway network: (i) Outer Circular Highway, (ii) Colombo–Katunayake Expressway, and (iii) 
Pinnaduwa–Godagama Expressway. In the long term, the government plans gradually to extend 
the expressway network toward the northern and eastern regions so that a trunk road network 
will be established comprising well-connected expressways and national roads.6 
 
7. 
With the insertion of an expressway network and expansion of major trading facilities, a 
number  of  challenges  are  emerging  for  the  road  transport  system.  The  access  routes  to  the 
Southern Expressway are usually congested. The roads connecting to the interchanges do not 
have sufficient capacity to absorb and distribute the expressway traffic throughput. This problem 
will  be  exacerbated  when  the  three  new  expressway  sections  are  completed.  The  investment 
into  improving  the  capacity  of  access  routes  remains  inadequate  because  (i)  the  road  sector 
competes for budget allocation with such other sectors as education, social, and health; and (ii) 
the fund-raising is inadequate in both the public and private sectors. Even with sufficient budget, 
the utilization would be less than optimal due to outdated design and construction technologies.  
 
8. 
 Limited capacity of road agencies for developing and managing the road sector assets 
is another cause of the connectivity problem. First, connectivity needs were not fully envisaged 
at  the  time  of  planning  the  expressway  network.  An  integrated  plan  to  ensure  connectivity 
between  the  expressway  and  local  transport  networks  was  not  adequately  prepared.  Second, 
the  design  standards  and  procedures  have  not  been  updated  to  address  the  requirements  of 
traffic  flow  in  expressway  interchange  areas  and  populated  areas,  as  well  as  to  incorporate 
measures  on  climate  change  adaptation,  maintenance,  and  road  safety.  Third,  the  traffic 
management  on  routes  with  heavy  traffic  is  not  effective.  Finally,  the  road  safety  policies  and 
regulations need to be enforced in their engineering and nonengineering aspects. 
 
9. 
To address road connectivity challenges in the southern region, the flows of passengers 
and  freight  need  to  be  facilitated  in  an  efficient  and  cost-effective  manner.  This  requires 
immediate  actions  on  two  aspects:  (i)  improving  the  capacity  of  the  access  routes  to  the 
expressway  network,  and  (ii)  enhancing  the  capacity  of  road  agencies  in  developing  and 
managing  the  road  sector  assets  by  preparing  a  long-term  connectivity  improvement  plan  that

number  of  development  partners,  including  the  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency,  the

Road Connectivity Project to be implemented by RDA. 
 
10. 
ADB  and  the  government  agreed  in  the  country  partnership  strategy,  2012–2016  that 
ADB’s  assistance  in  the  transport  sector  will  contribute  to  the  sector  outcome  of  improving 
nationwide  connectivity  for  the  movement  of  people  and  goods.8 ADB  is  financing  four  road 
projects  to  achieve  this  outcome,  but  most  of  these  are  in  the  northern  and  eastern  regions.9 
Although  not  included  in  the  country  operations  business  plan,  2012–2014, 10 the  proposed 
project  will  complement the  ongoing projects  in supporting the  sector  outcome.  Its  objective is 
also fully  in  line  with  the  government’s  sector  strategy  to  establish  a modern transport  system 
that will accelerate economic growth while reducing travel time and cost and improving safety. 
In  the  future,  ADB’s  assistance  will  focus  on  (i)  relieving  traffic  congestion  in  the  urban  areas 
and on the trunk roads, (ii) improving basic connectivity for the lagging regions and for important 
links,  and  (iii)  enhancing  the  sustainability  of  road  maintenance  scheme  at  national  and 
provincial levels. 
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

11. 
The impact of the project will be  an efficient road transport in  the southern region. The 
outcome will be improved connectivity between the expressway network and the local transport 
network in the southern region.  
 
C.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

The engineering design has been carried out for all project roads based on site condition 
18. 
surveys  and  field  investigations.  The  required  improvement  works  are  optimized  for  economy 
and  construction  efficiency  in  accordance  with  applicable  international  and  national  design 
standards.  The  construction  method  will  utilize  proven  technology  using  standard  materials 
compatible with local  conditions.  All  civil  works  contracts  will  also  include 5-year  performance-
based  maintenance  to  secure  maintenance  and  promote  private  sector  development.  The 
project  roads  have  been  assessed  for  climate  vulnerability  according  to  the  National  Climate 
Change  Adaptation  Strategy  for  Sri  Lanka.12 Key  risks  assessed  include  (i)  shifting  of  climate 
zones, (ii) floods, (iii) landslides, (iv) rise in sea level, and (v) drought exposure. The design of 
the project roads includes provisions for embankment rising and drainage enhancement. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

19. 
Economic  viability.  The  economic  analysis  was  carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB 
guidelines.13 The principal benefits calculated are savings in vehicle operating costs and travel 
time.14 The  estimated  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  is  18.3%.  Sensitivity  analysis 
indicates  that  the  project  has  an  EIRR  above  12%  even  with  adverse  variation  in  costs  and 
benefit streams. Therefore, the proposed improvements are economically viable. In addition to 
the quantified benefits, the project will bring significant benefits to overall regional development. 
Opening of the Southern Expressway has significantly reduced travel times along the corridor. 
The  improvement  of  project  road  sections,  which  provide  connectivity  to  the  Southern 
Expressway,  will  enhance  overall  network  connectivity  of  the  southern  region.  Industrial 
development will also benefit from the improved national roads, because the investment climate 
will  be  upgraded  by  better  connectivity  to  the  supply  sources  and  markets  outside  the  region. 
While such benefits are not quantified, these are the envisaged impacts of the project in relation 
to economic development and poverty reduction. 
 
20. 
Financial  sustainability.  The  unit  cost  related  to  operation  and  maintenance  of  the 
project  roads  will  decrease  after  construction  because  the  road  condition  will  be  improved.  In 
the long term, the required operation and maintenance costs for project roads represent only a 
very  small  proportion  of the  budget  allocation  (about  0.3%  of the  RDA maintenance budget  in 
2012). In view of recent trends, an adequate budget allocation is expected. The government has 
earmarked a budget amount for 5 years of performance-based maintenance, which covers both 
routine  and  periodic  maintenance.  It  is  reasonable  to  expect  the  project  to  be  financially 
sustainable. 
 
C. 

Governance 

21.

maintenance of the national highway network. RDA was established as a statutory authority with 
a separate legal personality by the Road Development Authority Act in 1981. RDA’s chairperson 
reports to the secretary of the Ministry of Ports and Highways (MOPH).

Poverty and Social 

D. 

26. 
Poverty  reduction  and  social  impact.  It  is  estimated  that  1.1  million  residents  in  the 
project areas are direct beneficiaries while the 4.6 million residents in three districts (Colombo, 
Kalutara,  and  Galle)  that  the  Southern  Expressway  spans  are  indirect  beneficiaries.  During 
focus  group  discussions  held  with  both  men  and  women,  most  respondents  stated  that  the 
proposed  road  rehabilitation  and  upgrading  will  help  create  new  economic  and  employment 
opportunities by improving links to markets, production centers, and other areas with economic 
opportunities. Access to public and social service facilities such as government agencies, health 
centers, and schools will also be improved. The project will have a short-term impact on poverty 
reduction, as the rural poor in project-impacted areas will be employed for construction. These 
will increase livelihood opportunities for those who now depend largely on occasional, uncertain 
employment.  The  contracts  for  civil  works  will  include  measures  to  ensure  safe  and  healthy 
working  environments  for  both  men  and  women  laborers.  The  contractors  will  be  required  to 
implement appropriate measures with respect to equal pay for equal work for men and women, 
health and safety at construction sites and labor camps, and an awareness program for workers 
on prevention of sexually transmitted infections.15 
 
27. 
Gender.  The  country  now  ranks  midway  on  the  United  Nations  Gender-related 
Development  Index.  Nationwide,  the  adult  literacy  rate  for  females  is  89.3%  as  compared  to 
94.5% for males. Women in project areas typically participate in household activities and some 
are  frequent  road  users  for  the  likes  of  transporting  children  to  school  and  visiting  markets. 
During  consultations,  women  indicated  that  improved  road  conditions  and  connectivity  will 
provide better access to health services, higher levels of education, economic opportunities, and 
social  interactions.  Time  savings  due  to  enhanced  road  conditions  increase  the  likelihood  of

more time being spent on productive activities, health care, and self-development. The project 
will aim to employ 15% women in road maintenance activities. It will provide employment skills 
development while enhancing personal financial management capacity for all women employed 
in civil works.16 No adverse impact on women due to the project is envisaged.  
 
28. 
A gender action plan has been prepared for the project in order to (i) maximize women’s 
access to project benefits such as by integrating features accommodative to the elderly, women, 
children,  and  the  disabled  into  road  design,  including  paved  and  raised  sidewalks,  paved 
shoulders,  and  road  safety  features;  (ii)  provide  opportunities  to  increase  women’s  skills, 
incomes,  and  participation  in  decision  making;  and  (iii)  minimize  social  vulnerability.  Practical 
and implementable gender mainstreaming activities have been incorporated into the project.17 
 
HIV/AIDS.  Sri  Lanka  is  recorded  to  have  a  low  HIV  prevalence  rate,  although  the 
29. 
number of reported cases has grown over the years. That is due in part to improved access to 
testing facilities. Countrywide responses have included establishment of the National STD and 
AIDS  Control  Program,  which  helps  to  refurbish  health  clinics  and  establish  outreach  and 
awareness  programs.  The  project  has  incorporated  measures  to  mitigate  HIV/AIDS  risks  by 
undertaking an awareness program for contractors at construction sites and for project-affected 
communities  at  prominent  village  locations.  Awareness-raising  activities  for  project-affected 
persons  will  be  conducted  separately  for  men  and  women  in  order  to  address  gender-specific 
issues.  
 
30. 
Human  trafficking.  Respondents  during  the  social  impact  assessment  did  not  identify 
human trafficking as a significant issue in the project area, although improved road connectivity 
may  trigger  movement  away  from  the  project  area  to  other  parts  of  the  country.  Civil  works 
contractors  are  anticipated  to  source  laborers  locally  and  will  not  require  migrant  workers. 
Affected communities will be provided with awareness training on human trafficking.

1. 

Involuntary Resettlement and Indigenous Peoples 

 
The  project  is  categorized  as  category  A  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
31. 
Statement (2009). All five project roads will be widened, which will create significant impact. Due 
to the  linear  nature  of that  impact, the majority  of  affected households will  lose  not  more than 
10%  of their  productive assets.  Some  commercial  structures  will  need  to  be  demolished since 
various  stretches  of  the  project  roads  traverse  urban  areas.  Impact  has  been mitigated  where 
possible  by  reducing  the  width  of  the  shoulder.  Three  resettlement  plans  have  been  prepared 
for  anticipated  land  acquisitions,  and  two  due  diligence  processes  regarding  land  acquisition 
have  been  undertaken  to  verify  previous  acquisitions  by  the  government.  All  these  have  been 
completed  in  accordance  with  government  regulations. 18 For  the  three  roads  requiring  land 
acquisition, it is estimated that 2,188 households including 9,641 persons will be affected. About 
488  households  comprising  approximately  2,150  persons  will  experience  significant  impact. 
Assistance will be in place to restore livelihoods to the same or better conditions compared with 
livelihood  conditions  at  the  pre-project  level.  For  the  two  roads  where  the  government  has 
already  acquired  land,  due  diligence  identified  15  households  due  interest  payments.  The 
government has allocated funds and these payments will be made prior to project approval. Civil
